description: A comprehensive dataset examining the relationship between sleep deprivation and cognitive performance metrics. The study collected data from 60 participants to analyze how sleep patterns affect reaction time, cognitive function, and stress levels. The research specifically focuses on measuring various aspects of cognitive decline and emotional regulation under different sleep conditions.

original_source.creator: Unknown
original_source.institution: Research Institution in Middle East (specific details not publicly available)
original_source.publication: Not yet published in academic journals

columns.name: Sleep_Duration
columns.semantic_description: Number of hours of sleep in the previous night

columns.name: Reaction_Time
columns.semantic_description: Measured response time to cognitive stimuli in milliseconds

columns.name: Daytime_Sleepiness
columns.semantic_description: Measured using Epworth Sleepiness Scale or similar metric

columns.name: Additional features
columns.semantic_description: Remaining features likely include cognitive performance metrics, physiological measurements, and other sleep-related variables (exact names not provided in source)

target_description.name: Stress_Level
target_description.meaning: Measured level of psychological stress, likely combining physiological and self-reported metrics

dataset_history: This dataset was collected as part of a 2024 study in the Middle East examining the relationships between sleep patterns and cognitive performance. The study appears to be designed to contribute to the growing body of research on sleep deprivation's effects on mental function and emotional regulation. The data collection involved 60 participants from diverse backgrounds, suggesting an attempt to capture a representative sample of the population.
inference_notes:
Important considerations for analysis include:
1. Relatively small sample size (60 participants) may limit generalizability
2. Regional specificity (Middle East) should be considered when applying findings to other populations
3. Self-reported measures may introduce reporting bias
4. The recent nature of the study (2024) means findings haven't been extensively peer-reviewed
5. Stress level measurements may be influenced by various external factors beyond sleep deprivation
6. The relationship between sleep and cognitive performance is likely non-linear and may involve complex interactions between variables
